title: Will humans ever extend their life span to 500 years or greater? - Quora

response.answer_text: It is not a matter of extending life per se, but extending the functional life as a human. Because extending the life of someone that’s not functional is not particularly useful. And extending the life of something that can’t really be considered a human is not “extending the life of humans”. A human is much like a car - made of many parts which wear out at different rates and all have a service life. So, to extend the life of a car you can either replace parts as they wear out or design a better car. Per available design virtually all parts of a human have a fixed service life much under 500 years. Maybe apart from skin and bones. So, the strategies of significant life extension would invariably involve gene editing and/or organ replacement. I don’t think that vitamins, dietary changes or some magic pill would give us a 5x life extension here. As for organ replacement, I do believe that as cloning tech advances we would be able to grow in a jar and replace most internal organs. Such procedures would be extraordinarily expensive and complicated, hence very rare. Sill, the obvious bottleneck would be that you can’t really replace the brain and it seems to have an expiration date of under 500 years. Maybe in some fantasy future we’d come up with some nanotechnology which would be able to physically encode brains doing a Ctrl+C/Ctrl+V on the hardware level. The software part of a human personality doesn’t seem to be the main component per se. I don’t see this tech emerging anytime soon. Plus, growing a functional brain in a jar might be far from trivial. As for gene editing, it might theoretically be possible to create something resembling a human which would have an arbitrary lifespan. You’d need to totally change the metabolism, re-engineer pretty much each and every system in the body and likely add a number of new ones. Which won’t be trivial. But, in principle that should be much easier to accomplish than growing/encoding a spare brain. Also, I am not sure that what we get as the final result would be a “human” in the classical sense. And such a construct would likely lack reverse compatibility with vanilla humans when it comes to reproduction making it a distinct species by any definition. Which has some obvious implications.

Such questions relating to those types of examples are pointless. The physiology of an earthworm versus a human fucking being is like comparing the complexity of a hand grenade to that of an ICBM. Extended lifespans is about more than just age, it involves the physical deterioration of the human body, which can self regenerate… to a degree. With the exception of the brain's nerve cells, which are irreparable once damaged or dead. To live for such an obscene amount of time would require those nerve cells to be replaced, and doing so organically rather than synthetically (your body replacing them rather than a brain transplant) is leagues beyond what we currently understand. Not to mention that the body itself can only regenerate cells for so long. Eventually, you break down like a machine. And unlike replacing a buggered oil filter or what have you, trying to replace the human liver, heart or skin is outside of what we can do right now, at least without the aid of immunosuppressive drugs. Which brings us to another concept. Disease. Alzheimers, Turings, Cancer and various other diseases can end the human life well beyond the natural lifespan. And on thr topicof premature death, you've not considered workplace hazards and just health hazards in general. Immortal or not, a bus travelling at 80km/h can kill you at any age.

The graph of life expectancy in the U.S. has been pretty much linear, going from 71 years to 78 years 1970-2010:  Do we see just a hint of some plateau over the last few years? Maybe ...  But look at Japan's curve, since it has the longest life expectancy of any major country in the world (thanks to Prof. David Roper):   Their curve definitely seems to be flattening as it approaches 85 years (it's almost there now, actually). You can see almost the same thing in Germany:   A lot depends less on medical science than on prosperity. It has taken a while for the eastern part of Germany to approach the life expectancy curve of the western part of Germany, but since unification in 1990, they are almost at equity now:  So barring unexpected breakthroughs, I think we in the U.S. can also expect to reach a "natural" limit of 85 in 2040 or so (unless we really want to keep people in poverty, as some are advocating). This apparent physical limit may not be so different from athletic performances, which are plateauing as well. It's not likely.  Most of the answers still suffer from the basic confusion of life expectancy versus life span. The short answer.  Increases in life expectancy are only improving the probability of surviving to the human life span.  They are NOT increases in lifespan. All the graphs, etc. are simply nonsense, because they are working on population averages which tells us nothing about actual life span.  In the 19th century there were people that lived into their 90's just as there are people today living into their 90's.  Life expectancy increases because the effect of infant mortality is decreasing.  That doesn't mean that anyone is actually living longer. In addition, the expectation that somehow modern technology is responsible for longevity is simply PR.  There is little evidence to suggest that modern technology has done anything for life span, although it clearly can affect individuals that had a higher probability of dying younger.   The current human lifespan is 120+ years.  Until life expectancy begins to approach this number, any talk about increasing life span is scientific nonsense.

If someone finds a way to stop aging living to thousands of years should be realistically possible. There is no fixed theoretical limit to human longevity just estimates based on who lived longest. Study finds there is no detectable limit to how long a person can live My guess is that probably sometime in the future humans will be living to beyond 500 years once old age is cured. Some scientists claim that the human that will live to a thousand years has already been born, Has the first person who'll live to 1,000 already been born? “Average human life span keeps increasing dramatically and maximum human lifespan seems to follow. I see no statistical or demonstrated biological reason how we would know that this must stop." - Siegfried Hekimi, How long can humans live?

I hope so. We’re on the brink of several potential longevity technologies, each with the promise of adding potentially months or years to a human’s lifespan. If these treatments are cumulative, it’s theoretically possible we’ll stretch our lifespans out to multiple centuries. In the event that there is a hard biological limit that prevents a single human body from lasting that long, it is often imagined that we may find a way around that in the form of mind uploading. However, nowhere near enough is known about the workings of the brain to make this anything more than a dream. Also, of course, a prerequisite to all of this is that we as a society treat people well enough that they could live that long, including healthcare. Even if we don’t actually make it to an average life expectancy of over 125 - even if that is impossible - we will be better off as a society for having tried.

In areas with good health care and strong clean food supplies life spans are increasing quite rapidly. What happens when life expectancy grows at a rate of more than 1 year per year? You have your 500 year life span, and I don't think it is very far off..Now lets get to work on making sure it is 500 healthy quality years. I also think it is important to get to work on right to die laws for those who don't want to make that 500 year journey.

Unless civilization will collapse or something will happen to prevent future scientific and technological development, in all likelihood, medical science will find a way at some point in the future to rejuvenate the human body and extend life expectancy to 500 years and more. The life expectancy of a person depends on their genetics and the environment (nutrition, hygiene, medical  care...). People in the last 100 years enjoyed the improvements in the environment while still having good genetics shaped by thousands of years of the evolution which gave us steady increase in the lifespan. Although we can expect the progress in the medical care to continue, the gene pool will eventually degrade. People who wouldn’t survive their childhood 100 years ago (me probably included) nowadays can live without problems long enough to have their own children. To be fair, this is a very slow process and although sometimes effects can be seen in the next generation, for the whole gene pool it will take dozens of generations to have a significant effect.On the other hand bacterias are still evolving and there are already superbugs immune to antibiotics which sends the medical care one step back. There are two solutions to this issue that should be combined: genetic engineering (not only to fix the faulty genes, but also to make new better ones too) and extensive use of body implants (especially electronic ones for brain to external world communication, eventually leading to immortal humans living in a virtual world). This is still probably not very popular nowadays and may lead us to the Borg-society, but without these steps the lifespan will reach a plateau at 85 years (as demonstrated by Laszlo B. Tamas) and then probably start to decrease.

Not really answering the question here but, would we want to? If the world is becoming more overpopulated, would it be a good thing? But, yes, to answer the question, we could possibly. Either though time travelling into the future, or harnessing the genetics of other species of animals which are already able to do it here on earth. So it may become possible, through these means, or via stem cells, or something else that hasn't come to mind...

A few humans may be able to extend their life span to 500 years: If some cars may be able to run for 5 million miles.If humans are transported to a no-gravity “no-threat” space.If humans are free of stress and worries.

There are really only two things we need in order to virtually eliminate aging,,,perfect, very rapid, dna repair (such as that found in a bacteria that lives inside nuclear reactors, like Staphylococcus radiofurans) and high production of the anti oxide super oxide dismutase…to minimize damage from inflammatory substances…engaging these in human dna could probably eliminate the need to replace defective cells, and thus the degradation of our telomeres…

Humans have already been under strong selection for longevity (K-selection) for hundreds of thousands of years, perhaps millions, so there may be little or no genetic variation available for selection or genetic engineering to act on to further extend our lifespan. The worms in question, conversely, have been under strong selection for a long time for rapid turnover (r-selection) so it may be relatively easy to select for the opposite.

Read Ray Kurzweil's "The Age of Spiritual Machines," in which he convincingly describes the Singularity, a moment in time when our exponentially increasing technological progress reaches a near vertical line and we have all downloaded our brains into computers and/or robot bodies. Looking at his graphs and extrapolations of our progress, this form of immortality should happen in well under 100 years.

No. There will not be enough food to keep people alive that long as long as we keep procreating like roaches without regard to the impact on the planet. There are, just for the record, limited resources.

The maximum possible human lifespan will never exceed about 125 years and only a small percent of the population will survive for more than 100 years. Furthermore, many of such very old people will develop Alzheimer’s disease before their death and not really enjoy their final years of life.
